Literature Review: Algorithmic fairness has become a pressing concern in the field of machine learning, as biased algorithms can perpetuate and even exacerbate existing social inequalities. This review aims to provide an overview of the recent literature on algorithmic fairness, with a particular emphasis on credit scoring. We will discuss human versus machine bias, bias measurement, group versus individual fairness, and a collection of fairness metrics. We will then apply these metrics to the US mortgage market, analyzing Home Mortgage Disclosure Act data on mortgage applications between 2009 and 2015. Our analysis reveals evidence of group imbalance in the dataset for both gender and minority status, which can lead to poorer estimation/prediction for female/minority applicants. We also find that loan applicants are handled mostly fairly across both groups and individuals, though we identify some instances of unfair treatment. Finally, we compare the performance of modern machine learning techniques to logistic regression, the industry standard, and discuss the implications of our findings for regulators, policymakers, and the courts.
